reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s practical upshot in §5—why to act as if broad convergence (scenario 3) is more decision-relevant than near-zero convergence (scenario 1), and specifically the anti-power-seeking recommendation that depends on assumed marginal tractability. That is meaningfully important but not the core thesis of the essay (which is mainly about likelihood of WAM/AM convergence, trade, threats, and blockers), so centrality is moderate. The argument has real force: the essay’s own discussion of lock-in, power concentration, and institutional choke points plausibly makes marginal influence highly non-linear, weakening the inference that ‘typical’ actors can shift Surviving/Flourishing by the implied amounts. However it doesn’t fully refute the essay’s step, because (i) the essay’s comparison is explicitly illustrative with rough numbers, (ii) the critique’s ‘near-zero influence’ and ‘already decent outcomes’ claims are plausible but not established, and (iii) many interventions could aim at shaping those very choke points, so the gap is more “needs a model / could fail” than a decisive contradiction. Most claims are reasonable and consistent with political economy considerations, though some are speculative, so correctness is fairly high but not perfect. The critique is focused, concrete, and has little fluff.
title: Nonlinear influence dynamics undercut the case for marginal convergence-focused action
